Since $PW \parallel QX$, $\angle USR = \angle RSQ$. Also, $\angle SUV = 120^\circ$. In $\triangle SUV$, $\angle SUV + \angle USV + \angle UVU = 180^\circ$.
In $\triangle VTX$, $\angle VTX = 112^\circ$.
Since $PW \parallel QX$, $\angle QTS = \angle STV$.
In $\triangle RUV$, $\angle UVR = \angle QXT$.
Since $PW \parallel QX$, $\angle RST = 180^\circ - (\angle TUV + \angle VTU) = 180^\circ - (120^\circ) = 60^\circ$
$\angle RSQ = \angle URS + \angle RSU$.
In $\triangle RTV$, $\angle TRV = \angle VTX = 112^\circ$.
$\angle URS = \angle SUV$ and $\angle UVT = \angle VTX$.
Since $PW \parallel QX$, alternate interior angles are equal.
$\angle VTU = \angle VTX$.
$\angle TUV = 180^\circ - (\angle UST + \angle SUT)$.
$\angle URV = 180^\circ - (\angle TRV + \angle RTV)$
$\angle VRT = 180^\circ - (180^\circ - \angle VTX - 120^\circ) = 180^\circ - (180^\circ - 112^\circ) = 112^\circ$.
$180 - (112 + 120/2)$.
Consider $\triangle STR$, $\angle STR + \angle RTS + \angle TSR = 180^\circ$.
$\angle USR + \angle SUR + \angle URS = 180^\circ$.
$\angle USV = \angle SUR$ (alternate interior angles).
$\angle VTU + \angle VTX = 120^\circ + 112^\circ = 232^\circ$.
$\angle VTR = 180^\circ - 120^\circ = 60^\circ$.
$\angle VRW = 180^\circ - \angle TUV - \angle VTX - 120^\circ$.
$\angle URT = \angle RST$.
$\angle RVT = 180 - 120 = 60$.
The problem states that $\angle SUV = 120^\circ$ and $\angle VTX = 112^\circ$.
$\angle SUR = \angle UST$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{68}$
ground_truth:
Since $SUR$ is a straight line, then $\angle RUV = 180^\circ - \angle SUV = 180^\circ - 120^\circ = 60^\circ$.

Since $PW$ and $QX$ are parallel, then $\angle RVW = \angle VTX = 112^\circ$.

Since $UVW$ is a straight line, then $\angle RVU = 180^\circ - \angle RVW = 180^\circ - 112^\circ = 68^\circ$.

Since the measures of the angles in a triangle add to $180^\circ$, then \[ \angle URV = 180^\circ - \angle RUV - \angle RVU = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 68^\circ = \boxed{52^\circ}. \]

Since $PW$ and $QX$ are parallel, then $\angle RVW = \angle VTX = 112^\circ$.

Since $UVW$ is a straight line, then $\angle RVU = 180^\circ - \angle RVW = 180^\circ - 112^\circ = 68^\circ$.

Since the measures of the angles in a triangle add to $180^\circ$, then \[ \angle URV = 180^\circ - \angle RUV - \angle RVU = 180^\circ - 60^\circ - 68^\circ = \boxed{52^\circ}. \]
